## 판결문 요약


91 Ill. App. 3d 1111 (1980)
415 N.E.2d 648
THE PEOPLE OF THE STATE OF ILLINOIS, Plaintiff-Appellee,
v.
MARTEASE THOMPSON, a/k/a Tony Richardson, a/k/a Victor Belton, Defendant-Appellant.
No. 79-2365.
Illinois Appellate Court  First District (2nd Division).
Opinion filed December 22, 1980.
*1112 James J. Doherty, Public Defender, of Chicago (Thomas E. Verdun, Assistant Public Defender, of counsel), for appellant.
Richard M. Daley, State's Attorney, of Chicago (Marcia B. Orr, Mary Ellen Dienes, and Bruce Rose, Assistant State's Attorneys, of counsel), for the People.
Judgment affirmed.
Mr. JUSTICE STAMOS delivered the opinion of the court:
After a bench trial, defendant Victor Belton[1] was convicted of aggravated assault and resisting arrest (Ill. Rev. Stat. 1977, ch. 38, pars. 12-2(a)(1) and 31-1) and sentenced to nine months in the House of Correction with credit for time already served. His motion for a new trial was denied and defendant appeals contending that his right to due process was violated by his arraignment 42 days after his warrantless arrest and that he was denied his constitutional right to confront the prosecution's witnesses against him.
The record indicates that defendant's case was initially called on August 23, 1979, two days after his arrest. At that time the court noted that defendant was in the hospital and entered a continuance to October 2, 1979.
